+Vicky Sanchez Thank you so much, Vicky. I even surprised myself ;) Graham 
Crackers would be a great substitution. You can use my homemade graham 
cracker recipe from my Homemade S'mores (http://bit.ly/gemmasmores) recipe. 
If you follow my method, you should get a similar consistency to 
gingerbread and not the hard graham crackers you can buy in a store. Let me 
know how you get on.

top_comment.author: FoodishBeauty

comments.text:
Thanks! My channel already have a good number of videos on there :) My 
channel is all about things I love in life, so not just baking, there's 
food, beauty, travel and fashion. Strangely enough I'm a trained makeup 
artist, a pastry chef and chocolatier lol, but now I'm just concentrating 
on establishing my channel, and gosh is it hard... Not the same as 15hr 
shifts in a kitchen but a different kind of challenge, but I'm slowly 
building a small community of subscribers and every time I read their 
comments, it always makes me smile and realise I love what I do now :) 
Please feel free to take a look at my channel, my baking videos all have a 
healthy twist to them as I love making something delicious without the 
guilt. And then there's beauty, fashion and fashion vlogs. Do hope you'll 
like it! If you scroll backwards enough to my 1st few videos, you'll see my 
chocolatier days when I assisted Ruth Hinks the UK Chocolate Master and 
followed her to France last year for the final. Seems like a life time ago 
now, but think the kitchen days will always run in my blood :) Sorry for 
the long essay, hope we can keep in touch, love the style of your channel!
comments.author: FoodishBeauty

comments.text: +FoodishBeauty let me know when you release a video :)
comments.author: Gemma Stafford

comments.text: Thank you for your encouraging words! :)

channel. It's a lot of work but very rewarding to help so many people enjoy 
baking.

comments.text:
very nice i like this idea and thought of a nice customization to go with 
it on the back wall leave an opening that can be used. on the back roof 
panel make a hole large enough for the chimney to go over. once everything 
is put together use the back door for a tea lite candle have it placed 
directly below the opening of the chimney so it can exhaust  the heat and 
not start fire. for obvious reasons the size of the structure needs to be 
large enough to accommodate the flame. with the stain glass windows effect 
it could give it a home like feel as if someone were inside sitting at a 
nice fire :)

captions.text: (Music)

Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking
Log Cabin Gingerbread House

Hi Bold Bakers! Christmas is almost here and
to celebrate I'm teaming up with some of my

great YouTube friends to bring you holiday
dessert ideas. You will see great holiday

desserts from Hot Chocolate Hits, Kawaii Sweet
World, The Squishy Monster, and Handle the Heat.

My contribution to this collaboration
is a BIG & BOLD Log Cabin Gingerbread House.
So let's get baking!

I have read all of your requests for a gingerbread
house, and to be honest with you this week

was the first time I've ever made one so I
really hope you like what I came up with.

We're going to start out by making our gingerbread
dough. If you don't have an electric mixer,

you can actually do it by hand just make sure
that your butter is room temperature.

To your mixer, you're going to add in your
butter and brown sugar and cream together

well. Now let's combine our dry ingredients
with our flour. Our ginger, cinnamon, cloves,

baking soda and salt. And then mix them all
well together.

When your butter and sugar is creamed, we're
going to add in the egg. Then turn your machine

back on and beat the egg until well combined.
Next add in your molasses. Now add in all

of your dry ingredients and mix to form a
dough.

Gingerbread is a perfect holiday cookie so
even if you don't get to make a house you

should definitely try and make gingerbread
men.

Ok. This looks great. This is what your gingerbread
dough should look like. It's nice and stiff,

and you can also give it a little taste. Mmmm.
Yummy.

Now we're going to wrap our dough in cling
film and let it rest in the fridge for around

an hour so it's going to be much easier to
work with.

Roll your dough on a well-floured surface
and make sure you move it around so it doesn't

stick. I'm rolling my dough to around a quarter
of an inch thick.

So I made my own template for cutting out
the gingerbread house. And I'm going to put

these measurements along with the recipe in
the description box below the video.

To cut out your house, I like to use a pizza
cutter but you can use a knife and just go
around the edges of your template.

For the ends of the house, you're going to
need to cut out two of these. I like to roll

out a little bit of dough at a time so it
stays cold and it's easier to work with.

Now cut out both of your roof pieces. And
then gently lift your house over to your baking tray.

These bigger squares are the front of the
house so we need two of these as well but

we're going to have to cut the windows and
the door out of one of them.

I'm going to put the measurements in the description
box below about where I cut them. Make sure

you save this guy because we need to bake
him.

And then along the same level, cut out your
windows. And I'm going to show you a really
fun trick to do something with the windows.

I'm also going to make a little chimney for
my house. These measurements are much smaller

but it makes such a nice addition to your
overall house. You'll need four pieces for
your chimney.

Because this is Bigger Bolder Baking, we're
going to give our gingerbread house stained

glass windows. We're going to put candies
in the holes where the windows are and when

it bakes it will melt and create a stained
glass window. It's going to look beautiful.

Bake your gingerbread at 350 degrees F for
around 10 minutes or until crisp around the outsides.

While our gingerbread is baking, we're going
to get our royal icing ready. You can buy

it in the store in dry form or you can actually
make your own. I'm going to put the recipe

that I used in the description box below.
The royal icing is going to be the glue that

holds our house together. And all it is is
like a thick frosting that will dry really hard.

Our timer has gone off so let's check on our
gingerbread. Our gingerbread is out of the

oven and it looks and smells great. We're
going to set this aside to go cold and then
we can start with our assembly.

If you like holiday recipes like I do then
give this video a thumbs up and for more great

recipes don't forget to subscribe to my channel.
Now this is my most favorite part: bringing
the gingerbread house to life.

Begin with the front and one of the sides.
Pipe your royal icing thick along the sides.

And then we're just going to start to piece
it together. Now to make sure that it stays

there we're going to put a tin in here to
hold it up.

Ok. Now we're going to add on the other side.
And we're going to do just like we did before.

Pipe frosting along the side. And then just
stick them together. And then again, another

tin. Now a good idea is to stand over the
house and just look down on it and make sure that
everything is as straight as it can be.

Now we're going to put on the back of the
house so we're going to put icing on both

of the sides. Then line it up with the rest
of the house so it's as straight as possible.

You can reinforce your frosting by just doing
it on the inside as well just to make sure
that everything is going to stick well together.

For the roof, similar to the wall you're going
to put frosting on both of the sides and then

along one of the sides. Then carefully place
it on. And just reinforce the roof by going

inside as well. And you can even go on the
outside too because we're going to cover all

of this up. You want to make sure that everything
stays exactly where it's supposed to.

The house is almost assembled but I'm going
to leave the last panel of the roof off because

I want to leave the tins in there, let the
house dry really hard, and then we'll put

this on. So next we're going to assemble our
chimney.

For the chimney it's the same deal, we're
going to stick the sides together. So then

this one goes here. I know this looks kind
of like a funny shape for a chimney but when

we put it on the roof you're going to see
the method to my madness. And for the last

little small piece, we're going to put frosting
on the sides. And then place it at the top.

You can prop it against something while it
sets.

Ok, so let's be honest. This gingerbread house
does not look very good. There are some holes.

It's all kind of wobbly. But that's why we're
making a log cabin gingerbread house. We are

going cover all of those imperfection with
pretzels.

So I'm using long, thick pretzels to resemble
logs for my log cabin. So all you want to

do is measure them to the size of your house.
If they're a little too big, get a serrated

knife and cut some off, and then stick it
to the house with royal icing. Putting on

your logs does not have to be perfect. Sometimes
a little bit of imperfection actually makes

it look a little bit more real. As you go
around the house, you can cut the pretzels

to fit the size so on the sides of the house
just keep on making them smaller and smaller

until you get that point. It's going to look
gorgeous! I hope by now you guys can see where

I'm going with this. It's really starting
to look like a log cabin.

Ok, so now that we've done the side of the
house we're going to move over to the front.

Just like the sides, cut your pretzels to
fit the frame. Make sure you save room to

add your door. Don't worry about this little
spot here because we're going to fill that

in later. The key to making your gingerbread
house is be patient and it will come together.

You can use your door to prop up this bit
and make sure it fits later. So as you can

see our house is getting there but it's still
a work in progress.

So we're going to let this set a little bit
and make some decorations to put on the house.

Using a star nozzle, pipe some royal icing
into the shape of a wreath. You can easily

dye your icing green. And then if you have
some little red decorations we're going to

make it look like holly. Next pipe some squiggly
lines for your garland. You will need around

three or four of them to string together.
Just like the wreath, we're going to pop on

a little color. These decorations need around
24 hours to dry so you can actually make them

the night before. And then the next day, this
is what they're going to look like: nice and

dry and they're going to look great on the
front of your house.

To give the front of the house some more color,
I'm going to paint the front door red. Just
with some red frosting that I made.

Now that the house is a little more stable,
we're going to put on the back of the roof.

Pipe your icing on all sides and then simply
place it on your house. And then to make sure
it sticks, just fill in these holes.

Now this is the part that I really like, when
it does start to look like a cabin, we are

going to put snow on the roof and around the
windows. It's going to look beautiful.

Simply start to pipe your royal frosting all
over the roof. The messier the better because

it makes really nice texture. Just do it anyway
you want. Because snow isn't uniform, and

it falls everywhere, I like to color it in
around the house to make it look like fresh

snow. These little parts that we didn't put
pretzels on, we are going to put snow on to
make it look like the windowsill.

Just to make it look a little bit more whimsical,
I like to add some white sugar to the top.

So our chimney is set, so we're going to put
it on the house. To stick your chimney onto

the house, put some more icing around the
edges. And then simply stick it flush onto

the roof. And that's why it's that funny shape
because it just fits right there. To make

it blend in a little bit more, we're going
to put snow on the top.

To stick on your garland, you can put it straight
into the icing. You can put some extra snow
around them.
Now place on your festive door.

And there you have it, a beautiful log cabin
gingerbread house made from scratch and it

wasn't nearly as much as work as you would
think it is.

If you enjoyed this video, please like and
share it. And make sure you check out all

the other fantastic videos in this playlist.
Don't forget to subscribe to my channel and

I'll see you back here again next Thursday
for more Bigger Bolder Baking.

title: How to Make a Gingerbread House Log Cabin (No Kit Required) - Gemma's Bigger Bolder Baking 47
